fir_rules.title: FIR Registration Simulation
fir_rules.description: First Information Report â€“ the first step in criminal proceedings

questions.scenario: A citizen arrives at a police station to report a cognizable offence (theft with force). The officer on duty must:

options.text: Register the FIR immediately without delay
Ask the citizen to come back tomorrow
Ask the citizen to first get a lawyer
Refuse as it is a minor issue

questions.explanation: Under Section 154 CrPC, police MUST register an FIR for cognizable offences immediately. Refusal is punishable under Section 166A IPC.
questions.consequence_if_wrong: Failure to register FIR can lead to departmental action and punishment under Section 166A IPC.

questions.scenario: An FIR has been registered. The informant wants to know who can file an FIR. Which of these is TRUE?

options.text: Only the victim can file an FIR
Any person who knows about the offence can file
Only a male family member can file
Only the police officer can file

questions.explanation: Any person who has knowledge of a cognizable offence can file an FIR. It is not limited to the victim alone.
questions.consequence_if_wrong: Misinformation about who can file leads to delayed justice for victims.

questions.scenario: After filing the FIR, the informant should receive:

options.text: Nothing, the police will handle everything
A free copy of the FIR
A receipt with a fee payment
Only a verbal confirmation

questions.explanation: Under Section 154(2) CrPC, a free copy of the FIR must be given to the informant immediately.
questions.consequence_if_wrong: Not providing a copy violates the informant's rights.

questions.scenario: A woman wants to file an FIR about sexual assault. The correct procedure is:

options.text: She must go to the police station in person
A female officer should record her statement at a convenient place
She must bring two male witnesses
She must first file a written complaint

questions.explanation: Under Section 154(1) proviso, the statement of a woman in cases of sexual assault shall be recorded by a female police officer at a convenient location.
questions.consequence_if_wrong: Violating this provision re-victimizes the complainant and is punishable.

questions.scenario: If the police station refuses to register an FIR, the citizen should:

options.text: Give up and go home
Pay a bribe to get it registered
Send the complaint to the Superintendent of Police by post
File a case in the Supreme Court directly

questions.explanation: Under Section 154(3) CrPC, if a police officer refuses to register an FIR, the informant can send the substance of the complaint to the Superintendent of Police.
questions.consequence_if_wrong: Citizens must know their legal remedies when police fail in their duties.

arrest_rules.title: Arrest Procedure Simulation
arrest_rules.description: Understanding the legal procedure during arrest

questions.scenario: A police officer is about to arrest a person. The FIRST thing the officer must do is:

options.text: Handcuff the person immediately
Inform the person of the grounds of arrest
Take the person to the police station silently
Call the person's family

questions.explanation: Under Article 22(1) of the Constitution, every arrested person must be informed of the grounds of arrest as soon as possible.
questions.consequence_if_wrong: Arrest without informing grounds is unconstitutional and can lead to habeas corpus proceedings.

questions.scenario: After arrest, the accused has a right to:

options.text: Consult a lawyer of their choice
Leave the police station freely
Destroy evidence
Refuse to give their identity

questions.explanation: Article 22(1) guarantees the right to consult and be defended by a legal practitioner of their choice.
questions.consequence_if_wrong: Denial of legal counsel makes the entire arrest procedure unlawful.

questions.scenario: Can police arrest a person without a warrant?

options.text: Yes, in all cases
No, never without a warrant
Yes, but only for cognizable offences
Only if the person is male

questions.explanation: Under Section 41 CrPC, police can arrest without warrant only in cognizable offences and under specific conditions laid down by the Supreme Court in Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar.
questions.consequence_if_wrong: Wrongful arrest without warrant leads to compensation under Article 21.

questions.scenario: A woman is being arrested. The correct protocol is:

options.text: She can be arrested at any time by any officer
She cannot be arrested after sunset and before sunrise except by a female officer
She must be arrested only with a magistrate present
Women cannot be arrested at all

questions.explanation: Under Section 46(4) CrPC, a woman cannot be arrested after sunset and before sunrise, except in exceptional circumstances with a written order from a Judicial Magistrate.
questions.consequence_if_wrong: Violation of this provision is a serious breach of women's rights.

questions.scenario: The arrested person must be produced before a magistrate within:

options.text: 48 hours
24 hours (excluding travel time)
72 hours
7 days

questions.explanation: Article 22(2) of the Constitution mandates that an arrested person must be produced before the nearest magistrate within 24 hours, excluding travel time.
questions.consequence_if_wrong: Detention beyond 24 hours without magistrate production is unconstitutional.

remand_rules.title: Magistrate Remand Simulation
remand_rules.description: Understanding remand procedures and rights during judicial custody

questions.scenario: Police custody remand (PCR) can be granted for a maximum of:

options.text: 30 days
15 days
60 days
90 days

questions.explanation: Under Section 167(2) CrPC, police custody remand cannot exceed 15 days in total. After that, the accused must be sent to judicial custody.
questions.consequence_if_wrong: Exceeding 15 days police custody is illegal detention.

questions.scenario: If the investigation is not completed within 90 days for offences punishable up to 10 years, the accused is entitled to:

options.text: Continued detention
Default bail (statutory bail)
Immediate acquittal
Transfer to another state

questions.explanation: Under Section 167(2) CrPC, if the investigation is not completed within 60 days (for offences with imprisonment up to 10 years) or 90 days (for graver offences), the accused gets the right to default bail.
questions.consequence_if_wrong: Failure to grant default bail violates the fundamental right to liberty under Article 21.

questions.scenario: During remand hearing, the magistrate MUST:

options.text: Simply sign the remand order
Examine whether the arrest was lawful and if custody is needed
Only listen to the police
Order punishment immediately

questions.explanation: The magistrate has a duty to apply judicial mind and examine whether the arrest was lawful, whether further custody is necessary, and whether the accused has been treated properly.
questions.article: Section 167, CrPC; CBI v. Anupam Kulkarni
questions.consequence_if_wrong: Mechanical remand orders violate Article 21 and have been criticized by the Supreme Court.

questions.scenario: An accused in judicial custody has the right to:

options.text: Be kept in solitary confinement
Meet their lawyer and family members
Leave jail whenever they want
Carry weapons for self-defense

questions.explanation: An accused in judicial custody has the right to meet their legal counsel, have family visits, and receive medical attention. These rights are protected under Article 21.
questions.consequence_if_wrong: Denying access to counsel or family is a violation of fundamental rights.

questions.scenario: The magistrate can refuse to grant police custody remand if:

options.text: The police bring the accused on time
There are visible signs of torture or ill-treatment on the accused
The crime is very serious
The accused is a first-time offender

questions.explanation: If the magistrate finds signs of torture, ill-treatment, or that the arrest is not lawful, they can and should refuse police custody remand. This is a constitutional safeguard.
questions.article: D.K. Basu v. State of West Bengal Guidelines
questions.consequence_if_wrong: Ignoring signs of custodial torture makes the magistrate complicit in rights violations.

basic_rights.title: Right to Know Grounds of Arrest
basic_rights.description: Every arrested person must be informed of the reason for their arrest immediately.

basic_rights.title: Right to Legal Counsel
basic_rights.description: Every arrested person has the right to consult a lawyer of their choice.

basic_rights.title: Right Against Self-Incrimination
basic_rights.description: No person can be compelled to be a witness against themselves.

basic_rights.title: Right to be Produced Before Magistrate
basic_rights.description: Must be presented before the nearest magistrate within 24 hours of arrest.

basic_rights.title: Right Against Torture
basic_rights.description: No person in custody can be subjected to torture or inhuman treatment.

basic_rights.title: Right to Free Legal Aid
basic_rights.description: If you cannot afford a lawyer, the State must provide one free of charge.

dos: Stay calm and cooperative during any police interaction
Ask for the officer's name and badge number
Request a copy of the FIR after filing
Inform a family member or friend about your arrest
Ask for a lawyer immediately upon arrest
Note the time and place of arrest
donts: Do not sign any blank papers
Do not make any confession without a lawyer present
Do not allow search without a warrant (for non-cognizable)
Do not provide false information in an FIR
Do not threaten or abuse police officers

quiz.question: If police refuse to register your FIR, you should:

options.text: Give up
Complain to the Superintendent of Police
Take the law into your own hands
Post about it on social media only

quiz.explanation: You can send the complaint to the SP by post under Section 154(3) CrPC.

quiz.question: Police can enter your house without a warrant:

options.text: Anytime they want
Only to prevent a cognizable offence or arrest a proclaimed offender
Never
Only during daytime

quiz.explanation: Police can enter without warrant only under specific circumstances like preventing a cognizable offence (Section 47, CrPC).

quiz.question: Your right to remain silent means:

options.text: You can refuse all communication with police
You cannot be forced to confess or testify against yourself
You should never talk to anyone
You must stay silent throughout the trial

quiz.explanation: Article 20(3) protects you from self-incrimination. You must provide identity details but cannot be forced to confess.

quiz.question: If arrested, you must be produced before a magistrate within:

options.text: 12 hours
24 hours
48 hours
7 days

quiz.explanation: Article 22(2) guarantees production before magistrate within 24 hours (excluding travel time).

quiz.question: Free legal aid is:

options.text: Only for rich people
A fundamental right under the Constitution
Not available in India
Only available in Supreme Court

quiz.explanation: Article 39A directs the State to provide free legal aid to ensure justice is not denied due to economic disability.
